content.title: Household Chores Exercise
content.instructions: Elige la respuesta correcta para completar cada oración sobre tareas del hogar.

questions.question: I have to clean the kitchen, but I can't find the mop. Have you seen ____?
questions.explanation: La palabra 'mop' es un sustantivo singular e inanimado, por lo tanto, el pronombre objeto correcto es 'it'.

questions.question: We should do the laundry today. There are ____ clothes in the basket.
questions.explanation: La palabra 'clothes' es un sustantivo contable en plural, por lo que el cuantificador correcto es 'many'.

questions.question: You have to wash the dishes now. You can't leave ____ in the sink overnight.
questions.explanation: La palabra 'dishes' es un sustantivo plural, por lo tanto, el pronombre objeto correcto es 'them'.

questions.question: Maria would like to bake a cake, but she can't find ____ recipe.
questions.explanation: Se utiliza 'the' antes de 'recipe' porque se refiere a una receta específica que Maria está buscando.

questions.sentence: Maria is planning to clean the living room tomorrow. She ______ (must/mustn't) forget to vacuum the carpet.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'must' para indicar obligación. Aquí, Maria tiene la obligación de no olvidar aspirar la alfombra.

questions.sentence: I ______ (can/can't) cook very well, but I can help you wash the dishes.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'can't' para indicar que no tenemos la habilidad o capacidad de hacer algo. En este caso, la persona no puede cocinar bien.

questions.sentence: Would you like to help me with the ______ (laundry/laundries) today?
questions.explanation: La palabra 'laundry' es un sustantivo incontable, por lo que no tiene plural.

questions.sentence: I think it will ______ (rain/rains) tomorrow, so we should clean the windows today.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'will' para hacer predicciones sobre el futuro. Aquí se predice que lloverá mañana.

questions.sentence: You ______ (should/mustn't) leave dirty dishes in the sink overnight.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'mustn't' para indicar prohibición. No está permitido dejar los platos sucios en el fregadero durante la noche.

questions.sentence: John ______ (is/are) going to the supermarket to buy some cleaning supplies.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'is' con la tercera persona singular en el presente continuo para planes futuros.

questions.sentence: They ______ (have to/has to) finish the chores before dinner.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'have to' con 'they' para expresar obligación.

questions.sentence: I would like to ______ (eat/eats) pizza for dinner tonight.
questions.explanation: Después de 'would like to', usamos el verbo en infinitivo sin 'to'. En este caso, 'eat'.

sentences.translation: El suelo no está lo suficientemente limpio.
sentences.hint: La estructura es: Sujeto + verbo + complemento + too/enough.
La estructura es: How many + sustantivo plural + have + sujeto + participio pasado + ?
La estructura es: Sujeto + need to + verbo + some + sustantivo.
La estructura es: Would + sujeto + like to + verbo + objeto + ?
La estructura es: Do + sujeto + not + have + any + sustantivo plural + ?

content.title: Speaking Analysis: Household Chores
content.instructions: Choose the most appropriate option for each speaking situation

questions.scenario: Your friend asks, 'Can you help me with the dishes?'
questions.question: What is the most natural response?
options: A. I can't do them now.
B. I am not able to do them now.
C. Sorry, I can't right now.
D. I will not do them now.
questions.explanation: La respuesta más natural y cortés en esta situación es 'Sorry, I can't right now.' Las otras opciones son demasiado formales o suenan bruscas.

questions.scenario: Someone says, 'The house is a bit messy, isn't it?'
questions.question: Choose the most appropriate idiomatic expression to reply.
options: A. It's as clean as a whistle.
B. It's raining cats and dogs.
C. It's not my cup of tea.
D. It looks like a bomb hit it.
questions.explanation: La expresión 'It looks like a bomb hit it' se usa para describir un lugar muy desordenado. Las otras opciones no son adecuadas en este contexto.

questions.scenario: You are discussing chores with a colleague.
questions.question: Which discourse marker is most appropriate to connect ideas?
options: A. Moreover, I need to clean the kitchen.
B. However, I need to clean the kitchen.
C. Therefore, I need to clean the kitchen.
D. Meanwhile, I need to clean the kitchen.
questions.explanation: La palabra 'Moreover' es adecuada para añadir información adicional. Las otras opciones no conectan correctamente las ideas en este contexto.

questions.scenario: Your friend is upset about having too many chores.
questions.question: Which response shows politeness and empathy?
options: A. You should just do it.
B. That's tough, do you need help?
questions.explanation: La respuesta 'That's tough, do you need help?' muestra empatía y ofrece ayuda, que es lo más cortés y apropiado en esta situación.

questions.scenario: You hear, 'I can't believe how dusty it is in here!'
questions.question: Which colloquial expression fits the casual context?
options: A. It's a piece of cake.
D. It's a walk in the park.
questions.explanation: La expresión 'It's a dust bowl' es una manera coloquial de describir un lugar con mucho polvo. Las otras opciones no son relevantes para el contexto.

content.title: Word Search: Household Chores
content.instructions: Find the hidden words in the grid

clues.clue: Remove dirt from something
Prepare food by heating it
Use a broom to clean the floor
Use water to clean something
Use a hot tool to remove wrinkles from clothes
Clean the floor with a wet tool
Remove dirt from surfaces
Clean using a machine that sucks up dirt
Rub something hard to clean it
Cook food by dry heat in an oven

content.title: Crossword: Household Chores
content.instructions: Complete the crossword puzzle

items.clue: Use a broom to clean the floor
Combine ingredients together
Clean dishes with water and soap
Remove dirt from surfaces
Make clothes smooth with heat
Prepare food using heat

content.title: Household Chores
content.text: Lucy is at home on Saturday. She can clean the house and cook meals. First, she takes a broom and sweeps the floor. Then, she uses a cloth to dust the furniture. After cleaning, Lucy goes to the kitchen. She can cook pasta for lunch. She likes to add vegetables and cheese. When her brother comes home, he helps her. He can wash the dishes after they eat. Lucy's mom can't help today because she is at work. In the evening, Lucy and her brother can watch TV. They feel happy because the house is clean and their chores are done. Lucy thinks she and her brother make a good team. They can relax because they did everything well.

questions.question: What is the main idea of the passage?
options: Lucy is visiting her friend on Saturday.
Lucy and her brother are doing household chores.
Lucy's mom is helping with chores.
Lucy is learning to cook new dishes.
questions.answer: Lucy and her brother are doing household chores.
questions.explanation: El pasaje describe cómo Lucy y su hermano realizan las tareas del hogar juntos durante el sábado.

questions.question: What does Lucy use to clean the floor?
questions.explanation: Lucy usa una escoba para barrer el piso, como se menciona en el pasaje.

questions.question: What can Lucy cook for lunch?
questions.explanation: El texto menciona que Lucy puede cocinar pasta para el almuerzo.

questions.question: Who helps Lucy with the dishes?
questions.explanation: El hermano de Lucy la ayuda a lavar los platos, como indica el texto.

questions.question: Lucy's mom can help with chores today. True or False?
questions.explanation: La mamá de Lucy no puede ayudar hoy porque está en el trabajo, según el pasaje.

questions.question: What do Lucy and her brother do after the chores?
questions.explanation: Después de terminar las tareas, Lucy y su hermano pueden ver la televisión.

content.title: Práctica de pronunciación: Estrés de palabras
content.instructions: Practica la pronunciación de las siguientes oraciones enfocándote en el estrés de palabras. Escucha atentamente el audio y presta atención a las sílabas acentuadas.

targetSentences.english: I have to clean the big kitchen.
targetSentences.spanish: Tengo que limpiar la cocina grande.
targetSentences.phoneticTranscription: /aɪ hæv tə kliːn ðə bɪɡ ˈkɪʧɪn/
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Enfatiza la primera sílaba de 'kitchen'.
targetSentences.focusPoints: Acentuar correctamente la primera sílaba de 'kitchen'.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No omitir el acento en 'kitchen'.

targetSentences.english: He will cook the dinner tonight.
targetSentences.spanish: Él cocinará la cena esta noche.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Asegúrate de enfatizar 'cook' y 'dinner'.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No enfatizar 'cook' podría cambiar el significado.

targetSentences.english: She must wash the clothes carefully.
targetSentences.spanish: Ella debe lavar la ropa cuidadosamente.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Enfatiza 'wash' y 'clothes'.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: Evitar acentuar incorrectamente 'must'.

targetSentences.english: I can’t find the vacuum cleaner.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Acentúa 'vacuum' y 'cleaner'.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No olvidar acentuar 'vacuum'.

targetSentences.english: We should dust the living room.
targetSentences.spanish: Debemos quitar el polvo de la sala de estar.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Enfatiza 'dust' y 'living'.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No olvidar acentuar 'living'.

content.title: Household Chores Practice
content.instructions: Selecciona la opción correcta. Lee con atención cada pregunta sobre tareas del hogar.

questions.question: I have to clean the kitchen today. Can you help ___ with it?
questions.explanation: La opción correcta es 'me' porque es el pronombre objeto que se usa después de un verbo para referirse a la persona que recibe la acción.

questions.question: We don't have ___ milk left. Can you buy some at the store?
questions.explanation: Usamos 'any' con sustantivos incontables en oraciones negativas como en este caso, ya que no queda leche.

questions.question: You should ___ the floor before dinner. It's really dirty.
questions.explanation: Después de 'should', el verbo va en su forma base, que en este caso es 'sweep'.

questions.question: How ___ plates do we need for the party?
questions.explanation: Usamos 'many' con sustantivos contables en preguntas para preguntar por cantidad, como en este caso con 'plates'.

questions.question: She can't find her keys. Can you help her look for ___?
questions.explanation: La opción correcta es 'them' porque es el pronombre objeto que se usa para referirse a objetos en plural, como 'keys'.

questions.sentence: I'm going to clean the kitchen. I have bought ___ new sponge for it.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'a' antes de palabras que empiezan con consonante y se refieren a algo no específico.

questions.sentence: There isn't ___ milk left in the fridge, so I'm going to buy some.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'any' en oraciones negativas con sustantivos incontables para indicar la ausencia de algo.

questions.sentence: She should buy ___ vegetables for the dinner tonight.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'some' en oraciones afirmativas para referirnos a cantidades no especificadas de sustantivos contables o incontables.

questions.sentence: We don't have ___ eggs to make a cake.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'many' con sustantivos contables en oraciones negativas e interrogativas para indicar cantidad.

questions.sentence: The living room isn't big enough for ___ furniture.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'much' con sustantivos incontables en oraciones negativas e interrogativas para indicar cantidad.

questions.sentence: You should help ___ with the cleaning every weekend.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'them' como pronombre objeto para referirnos a 'ellos/ellas'.

questions.sentence: Is there ___ bread left? I want to make a sandwich.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'any' en preguntas con sustantivos incontables para preguntar por la existencia de algo.

questions.sentence: I have to buy ___ apples for the pie.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'many' con sustantivos contables en oraciones afirmativas para preguntar la cantidad.

sentences.hint: Pregunta con 'can' para habilidad.
Usa 'have to' para expresar obligación.
Usa 'should' para dar consejos.
Usa 'can't' para expresar incapacidad.
Pregunta con 'can' para habilidad.

content.title: Speaking Analysis: Household Chores
content.instructions: Choose the most appropriate option for each speaking situation

questions.scenario: You are talking to your friend about who should clean the house.
questions.question: Who can clean the kitchen today?
questions.explanation: La respuesta más adecuada es 'I can do it.' porque muestra disposición para hacer la tarea, que es lo que se espera al preguntar quién puede limpiar la cocina.

questions.scenario: You are politely asking your neighbor to lower the volume as you want to focus on cleaning.
questions.question: What is the most polite way to ask?
options: Can you lower the volume, please?
questions.correctAnswer: Can you lower the volume, please?
questions.explanation: La opción 'Can you lower the volume, please?' es la manera más cortés y adecuada de hacer una solicitud.

questions.scenario: You are in a casual conversation with your friend about doing laundry.
questions.question: What is the informal way to express that you can't do laundry today?
options: I'm not able to do laundry.
I am unable to do laundry.
Laundry is not possible today for me.
questions.explanation: La frase 'I can't do laundry today.' es la manera más informal y directa de expresar la imposibilidad de realizar la tarea.

questions.scenario: Your family is deciding who should cook dinner tonight.
questions.question: What is the most natural way to suggest someone else cooks?
questions.explanation: La opción 'Maybe you can cook tonight.' sugiere de manera natural y educada que otra persona se encargue de cocinar.

questions.scenario: You are explaining why you can't help with chores.
questions.question: Which phrase explains your inability naturally?
options: I can not help because I'm busy.
I can't help because I'm busy.
Help is not possible for me.
questions.correctAnswer: I can't help because I'm busy.
questions.explanation: La opción 'I can't help because I'm busy.' es la manera más natural y común de explicar la imposibilidad de ayudar.

questions.scenario: You are offering help with cleaning to a friend.
questions.question: What is the most appropriate offer?
options: I will assist you in cleaning.
questions.explanation: La opción 'I can help with cleaning.' es directa y muestra claramente la disposición para ayudar.

content.title: Word Search: Household Chores
content.instructions: Find the hidden words in the grid.

clues.clue: To make something free from dirt.
To prepare food by heating it.
To remove dirt or dust with a broom.
To remove dust from surfaces.
To make clothes smooth using heat.
To clean with water and soap.
To clean floors using a machine that sucks up dirt.
To clean something by rubbing hard.
To clean floors using a wet tool.
To remove moisture.

content.title: Crossword: Household Chores
content.instructions: Complete the crossword puzzle

items.clue: Remove dirt from surfaces
Use a broom to clean the floor
Clean the floor with water and a mop
Prepare food to eat
Use this tool to make clothes smooth
Clean dishes with water and soap
Use a machine to clean the carpet

content.title: Daily Household Chores
content.textPassage: Every morning, Lucy wakes up early to start her day. She can clean the kitchen and make breakfast for her family. Lucy loves cooking, and she often tries new recipes. She also needs to tidy up the living room before her children wake up. Her husband, Tom, helps her with the chores. He can vacuum the floors and take out the trash. They work together to keep the house clean. On weekends, Lucy and Tom do the laundry. They wash their clothes and hang them to dry outside. Lucy thinks that doing chores together is fun because they talk and laugh. In the evening, they relax and enjoy dinner. Lucy is happy when everyone helps with the household chores.

questions.question: What does Lucy do every morning?
options: She cleans the kitchen and makes breakfast.
questions.correctAnswer: She cleans the kitchen and makes breakfast.
questions.explanation: Lucy limpia la cocina y prepara el desayuno cada mañana, como se menciona en el texto.

questions.question: What is Tom's chore in the house?
options: He vacuums the floors and takes out the trash.
questions.correctAnswer: He vacuums the floors and takes out the trash.
questions.explanation: Tom pasa la aspiradora y saca la basura, según el texto.

questions.question: What does Lucy think about doing chores together?
options: She thinks it's a waste of time.
questions.explanation: Lucy cree que hacer las tareas juntos es divertido porque pueden hablar y reírse.

questions.question: What do Lucy and Tom do on weekends?
questions.explanation: Durante los fines de semana, Lucy y Tom lavan la ropa y la tienden afuera.

questions.question: True or False: Lucy cooks every evening.
questions.explanation: El texto no menciona que Lucy cocine todas las noches, solo que disfrutan de la cena.

questions.question: What is NOT mentioned in the text?
questions.explanation: El texto no menciona que tengan una mascota.

content.title: Práctica de Pronunciación: Enfoque en el Estrés de Oración
content.instructions: Practica cómo enfatizar las palabras correctas en las siguientes oraciones. Esto te ayudará a sonar más natural cuando hablas en inglés. Escucha las oraciones y sigue los consejos de pronunciación.

targetSentences.english: I can clean the kitchen tomorrow.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Enfatiza 'clean' y 'kitchen' para mostrar que estas son las acciones importantes.
targetSentences.focusPoints: Palabras clave como 'clean' y 'kitchen' deben ser más fuertes.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No pongas demasiado estrés en 'can' ya que es una palabra auxiliar.

targetSentences.spanish: Ella puede cocinar la cena esta noche.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Enfatiza 'cook' y 'dinner' para destacar las acciones importantes.
targetSentences.focusPoints: Palabras clave como 'cook' y 'dinner' deben ser acentuadas.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No pongas demasiado estrés en 'can'.

targetSentences.english: We must wash the dishes after eating.
targetSentences.spanish: Debemos lavar los platos después de comer.
targetSentences.phonetic: /wi mʌst wɒʃ ðə ˈdɪʃɪz ˈæftər ˈiːtɪŋ/
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Enfatiza 'wash' y 'dishes' para mostrar la importancia de la tarea.
targetSentences.focusPoints: Acentúa 'wash' y 'dishes' más que otras palabras.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: Evita acentuar demasiado 'must'.

targetSentences.english: They can't vacuum the room now.
targetSentences.spanish: Ellos no pueden pasar la aspiradora en la habitación ahora.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Enfatiza 'vacuum' y 'room' para resaltar qué no se puede hacer.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No acentúes excesivamente 'can't'.

targetSentences.english: You should dust the shelves today.
targetSentences.spanish: Deberías quitar el polvo de las estanterías hoy.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Enfatiza 'dust' y 'shelves' para indicar la acción principal.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No pongas demasiado estrés en 'should'.

content.title: Household Chores: Object Pronouns and Modals
content.instructions: Choose the correct answer for each question.

questions.question: Can you clean the kitchen? I need you to do ___ now.
questions.explanation: La cocina es un objeto singular, por lo tanto, usamos 'it' para referirnos a ella.

questions.question: We have to finish our chores. Mom will help us with ___.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'them' porque 'chores' es plural y es el objeto del verbo 'help'.

questions.question: I can't cook dinner tonight. Can you do ___ for me?
questions.explanation: 'It' se usa aquí para referirse a 'dinner', que es singular.

questions.question: The windows are very dirty. You should clean ___ today.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'them' porque 'windows' es plural y es el objeto del verbo 'clean'.

questions.question: Can you help me with the laundry? I can't do ___ alone.
questions.explanation: 'Laundry' es un objeto singular, por lo que usamos 'it'.

questions.sentence: I can't find my keys. Have you seen ______ anywhere?
questions.explanation: En esta oración, 'keys' es plural, por lo que usamos el pronombre de objeto 'them' para referirnos a ellas.

questions.sentence: Can you help me with the dishes? I can't do ______ by myself.
questions.explanation: La palabra 'dishes' es plural, así que usamos 'them' para referirnos a los platos.

questions.sentence: She is cooking dinner. Can you ask her if she needs any help with ______?
questions.explanation: La acción de 'cooking dinner' se refiere a una sola cosa, por lo que usamos 'it' para referirnos a la cena.

questions.sentence: My brother is vacuuming the living room. He can't hear ______ right now.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'me' porque es el pronombre de objeto correcto para referirse a uno mismo en este contexto.

questions.sentence: We have to clean the windows today. Can you help us with ______?
questions.explanation: La palabra 'windows' es plural, así que usamos 'them' para referirnos a las ventanas.

questions.sentence: She can't reach the top shelf. Can you help ______?
questions.explanation: Usamos 'her' porque es el pronombre de objeto correcto para referirse a ella en este contexto.

questions.sentence: We are planning to clean the house tomorrow. Can you join ______?
questions.explanation: Usamos 'us' porque es el pronombre de objeto que se usa para incluirse a uno mismo y a otros.

questions.sentence: I have bought some new cleaning products. Can you put ______ under the sink?
questions.explanation: La frase 'some new cleaning products' es plural, por lo que usamos 'them' para referirnos a los productos.

sentences.hint: Usa 'have to' para obligación.

sentences.translation: Las manzanas son lo suficientemente deliciosas.
sentences.hint: Usa 'enough' después del adjetivo.

sentences.translation: Tom es más alto que su hermano.
sentences.hint: Usa un adjetivo comparativo con 'than'.

sentences.translation: Esta es la casa más grande.
sentences.hint: Usa un adjetivo superlativo.

sentences.translation: No tenemos que lavar los platos.
sentences.hint: Usa 'don't have to' para expresar ausencia de obligación.

content.title: Speaking Analysis: Household Chores
content.instructions: Choose the most appropriate option for each speaking situation

questions.scenario: You are talking to a friend about cleaning the house.
questions.question: Your friend says, 'I can't clean the windows. Can you help me with them?' What is the best response?
options: A) I'm sorry, I can help you later.
B) No, I can't help them.
C) Yes, I will help them.
D) Sure, I can help you with them.
questions.explanation: La respuesta más apropiada es 'Sure, I can help you with them' porque usa un pronombre de objeto correcto y muestra disposición para ayudar.

questions.scenario: You are in a casual conversation with a neighbor about cooking dinner.
questions.question: Your neighbor says, 'I can't cook well, but I can make pasta.' What would be your informal response?
options: A) That's great. Pasta is delicious.
B) I am pleased you can do it.
C) Wow, you should try harder.
D) I can't do it either.
questions.explanation: La respuesta 'That's great. Pasta is delicious.' es informal y positiva, adecuada para una conversación casual.

questions.scenario: You are discussing weekend plans with a colleague.
questions.question: Your colleague says, 'I can clean the garage on Saturday.' Which response uses a discourse marker correctly?
options: A) So, you are busy then.
C) Because, I can do that.
D) Or, I can help you.
questions.explanation: 'So, you are busy then.' usa un marcador discursivo correcto ('So') para conectar con lo que ha dicho el colega.

questions.scenario: You are at a friend's house and they ask you to help with chores.
questions.question: Your friend says, 'Can you do the dishes?' What is the most polite response?
options: C) Yes, I can do them.
D) Sorry, I can't do them right now.
questions.explanation: 'Sorry, I can't do them right now.' es una respuesta educada porque empieza con una disculpa antes de rechazar la solicitud.

questions.scenario: You are discussing cleaning habits with a friend.
questions.question: Your friend says, 'I can never find time to vacuum.' How do you respond using a colloquial expression?
options: B) That's the way it is.
questions.explanation: 'Join the club.' es una expresión coloquial que se usa cuando alguien comparte una dificultad común.

questions.scenario: You are at a dinner party and someone comments on the food.
questions.question: A guest says, 'I can't believe how good this tastes!' How do you respond with cultural understanding?
options: A) Yes, I cooked it myself.
B) It is okay, I guess.
C) Thank you, we had help from a chef.
questions.explanation: 'Thank you, we had help from a chef.' es una respuesta adecuada culturalmente, mostrando gratitud y reconocimiento a quien ayudó.

content.title: Word Search: Household Chores
content.instructions: Find the hidden words in the grid

clues.clue: Make something free from dirt or mess
Prepare food by heating it
Use a broom to remove dirt from the floor
Remove small particles from surfaces
Washing of clothes
Make clothes smooth using heat
Clean with water and soap
Clean the floor with a wet tool
Wash something with clean water to remove soap
Cook in an oven using dry heat

content.title: Crossword: Household Chores
content.instructions: Complete the crossword puzzle

items.clue: You need to do this to keep the house tidy.
You wash these after eating.
You use a broom to do this.
This machine helps to clean carpets.
You do this to make food ready to eat.
You take this out when it's full.
You do this to clean your clothes.
Use this tool to clean the floor with water.

content.title: Household Chores
content.textPassage: Do you like doing household chores? Some people enjoy cleaning and cooking, while others can't stand it. In my house, everyone has their own chores. I can clean the windows, but I can't cook very well. My sister loves cooking. She can make delicious meals, and I help her by washing the dishes. My brother can't vacuum the floor, so I do it for him. My parents can do almost everything, but they like us to help. They say it makes us more responsible. On Saturdays, we clean the house together. I think it's a good way to learn how to do things by myself. What about you? Can you do your chores alone or do you need help?

questions.question: What is the main idea of the passage?
options: The writer loves doing all household chores.
The writer's family shares household chores.
The writer's parents do all the chores.
questions.answer: The writer's family shares household chores.
questions.explanation: La idea principal del texto es que la familia del autor comparte las tareas del hogar.

questions.question: Who loves cooking in the writer's family?
questions.explanation: La hermana del autor es la que ama cocinar.

questions.question: What chore does the writer help with?
questions.explanation: El autor ayuda lavando los platos.

questions.question: True or False: The writer can vacuum the floor.
questions.explanation: El autor menciona que puede aspirar el suelo, a diferencia de su hermano.

questions.question: Why do the writer's parents want the children to help with chores?
options: Because they can't do the chores
questions.explanation: Los padres quieren que los niños ayuden para hacerlos más responsables.

questions.question: What does the writer think about cleaning the house together?
options: It's a good way to learn.
questions.answer: It's a good way to learn.
questions.explanation: El autor cree que limpiar la casa juntos es una buena manera de aprender.

questions.question: Which chore can't the writer do very well?
questions.explanation: El autor menciona que no puede cocinar muy bien.

content.title: Práctica de Pronunciación: Minimal Pairs
content.instructions: Practica la pronunciación de palabras similares que suenan de manera diferente. Escucha el modelo de audio (enlace proporcionado) y repite cada oración. Presta atención a las diferencias en los sonidos.

targetSentences.englishSentence: She cleans the kitchen every day.
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: Ella limpia la cocina todos los días.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Fíjate en la pronunciación de 'cleans' /kliːnz/ y 'kitchen' /ˈkɪtʃɪn/. La 'ch' en 'kitchen' suena como /tʃ/.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No confundir el sonido /ʃ/ con /s/.

targetSentences.englishSentence: He can cook a meal.
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: Él puede cocinar una comida.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Nota la diferencia entre 'can' /kæn/ y 'cook' /kʊk/. La 'oo' en 'cook' tiene un sonido corto.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: Evitar pronunciar 'can' como /kən/.

targetSentences.englishSentence: She must dust the shelves.
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: Ella debe desempolvar los estantes.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Enfócate en 'must' /mʌst/ y 'dust' /dʌst/. Ambos tienen el sonido /ʌ/.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No pronunciar 'must' como /muːst/.

targetSentences.englishSentence: They can't find the mop.
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: No pueden encontrar el trapeador.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Observa la pronunciación de 'can't' /kænt/ y 'mop' /mɒp/. 'Can't' tiene un sonido nasal.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No decir 'can't' como /kɑːnt/.

targetSentences.englishSentence: I have to vacuum the carpet.
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: Tengo que aspirar la alfombra.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Fíjate en 'vacuum' /ˈvækjuːm/ y 'carpet' /ˈkɑːrpɪt/. Ambos comienzan con un sonido fuerte.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: Evitar pronunciar 'vacuum' como /ˈveɪkjuːm/.

content.title: Household Chores and Abilities
content.instructions: Choose the correct answer for each question.

questions.question: Maria can cook very well. What does she need to prepare dinner?
questions.explanation: La respuesta correcta es 'Her' porque necesitamos un pronombre objeto para indicar lo que Maria necesita. 'Her' es el pronombre objeto correcto aquí.

questions.question: Carlos can't clean the windows. Can you help ____?
questions.explanation: La respuesta correcta es 'him' porque es el pronombre objeto que sigue al verbo 'help'.

questions.question: We have to finish the laundry. Who is going to fold ____ clothes?
questions.explanation: La respuesta correcta es 'them' porque es el pronombre objeto que se utiliza para referirse a 'the clothes'.

questions.question: Anna is going to vacuum the living room. She can do it by ____.
questions.explanation: La respuesta correcta es 'herself' porque es un pronombre reflexivo que se usa para indicar que Anna puede hacer la tarea sola.

questions.sentence: Maria ___ (have to) clean the kitchen before dinner.
questions.explanation: En inglés, 'have to' se usa para expresar obligación. Con 'Maria' (tercera persona singular), usamos 'has to'.

questions.sentence: You ___ (mustn't) leave the dishes dirty.
questions.explanation: 'Mustn't' se usa para expresar prohibición. Aquí, no está permitido dejar los platos sucios.

questions.sentence: It's too late. We ___ (will) do the laundry tomorrow.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'will' para hacer predicciones o decisiones futuras. Aquí, se predice que la colada se hará mañana.

questions.sentence: The basket is too heavy. She ___ (can) carry it alone.
questions.explanation: 'Can't' se usa para expresar falta de habilidad. Ella no puede llevar la cesta sola porque es demasiado pesada.

questions.sentence: They ___ (would like to) have dinner at a new restaurant.
questions.explanation: 'Would like to' se usa para expresar deseos. Aquí, ellos desean cenar en un restaurante nuevo.

questions.sentence: You ___ (should) vacuum the carpet. It looks dirty.
questions.explanation: 'Should' se usa para dar consejos. Se aconseja pasar la aspiradora porque la alfombra está sucia.

questions.sentence: The children ___ (must) tidy their room before playing.
questions.explanation: 'Must' se usa para expresar obligación. Los niños deben ordenar su habitación antes de jugar.

questions.sentence: I ___ (don't have to) cook tonight; we're ordering pizza.
questions.explanation: 'Don't have to' indica que no hay obligación. No es necesario cocinar porque se va a pedir pizza.

sentences.hint: La estructura es: sujeto + can + verbo + objeto.

sentences.translation: Él está aspirando la sala de estar.
sentences.hint: Usa el presente continuo: sujeto + is/am/are + verbo-ing.

sentences.translation: Ellos no pueden alcanzar los estantes altos.
sentences.hint: La estructura es: sujeto + can't + verbo + objeto.
La estructura es: sujeto + have to + verbo + objeto.
La estructura es: sujeto + can + verbo + objeto.

content.title: Speaking Analysis: Household Chores
content.instructions: Choose the most appropriate option for each speaking situation

questions.scenario: Sarah is talking to her neighbor about cleaning the house.
questions.question: Sarah: 'I can't clean the windows because they are too high. Can you help me?' Neighbor: 'Sure, I can help you. ______.'
options: B: You should do it yourself.
C: I can't reach them either.
questions.explanation: La opción A es la más apropiada porque el vecino está ofreciendo ayuda activa, mencionando que traerá una escalera, lo que es una respuesta útil y relevante.

questions.scenario: You are discussing cooking dinner with your friend.
questions.question: Friend: 'Can you cook pasta tonight?' You: 'I can't cook pasta, but ______.'
options: A: I can make a salad.
B: I can do the dishes.
questions.explanation: La opción A es la correcta porque ofrece una alternativa viable para la cena, que es hacer una ensalada.

questions.scenario: During a discussion about household chores, someone asks your opinion.
questions.question: Person: 'What do you think about sharing chores?' You: 'I believe sharing chores is important because ______.'
options: C: I can be lazy sometimes.
questions.explanation: La opción A es la más adecuada ya que explica por qué compartir las tareas es positivo, mencionando que hace la vida más fácil.

questions.scenario: You are at a party and someone asks about your ability to cook.
questions.question: Person: 'Can you make a cake?' You: 'I can make a cake, but ______.'
questions.explanation: La opción A es correcta porque indica que puedes hacer un pastel pero necesitas ingredientes, lo cual es relevante para la acción de cocinar.

questions.scenario: You are talking to a friend about cleaning the house.
questions.question: Friend: 'Can you clean the kitchen today?' You: 'I can't clean the kitchen today because ______.'
options: A: I have to work late.
D: I will be on vacation.
questions.explanation: La opción A es la más adecuada ya que ofrece una razón válida y comprensible para no poder limpiar la cocina hoy.

content.title: Word Search: Household Chores
content.instructions: Find the hidden words in the grid.

clues.clue: To clean the floor with a broom.
To clean the floor with water.
To remove dirt from surfaces.
To prepare food using heat.
To clean with water and soap.
To remove wrinkles from clothes.
To make something free of dirt.
To clean floors using a machine that sucks up dirt.

content.title: Crossword: Household Chores
content.instructions: Complete the crossword puzzle

items.clue: You use a broom to do this. (Can you do it?)
Remove this from furniture with a cloth.
You do this in the kitchen to make food.
You do this to the dishes after eating.
Use a machine to clean the floor. (Can you do it?)
You do this to clothes to make them smooth.
You do this to the floor with water.

content.title: Household Chores: Cleaning and Cooking
content.textPassage: Anna lives in a small apartment and she has a lot of household chores to do every week. She usually cleans her apartment on Saturday. She can clean the living room and kitchen very quickly, but she can't reach the top shelves, so she asks her friend to help her. Anna enjoys cooking, and she often makes dinner for her friends. She can make pasta and salads, but she can't bake cakes very well. Her friends love her pasta and always ask for more. After cooking, she has to wash the dishes, but she doesn't mind because she listens to music while she does it. On Sundays, Anna does the laundry. She can wash her clothes without any problems, but she doesn't like ironing them. Luckily, her friend likes to iron, so they often help each other with chores. Anna thinks that sharing chores makes them easier and more fun.

questions.question: What is the main idea of the passage?
options: Anna shares chores with her friend.
Anna can bake cakes very well.
Anna cleans her apartment every day.
questions.answer: Anna shares chores with her friend.
questions.explanation: La idea principal es que Anna comparte las tareas del hogar con su amiga, lo que las hace más fáciles y divertidas.

questions.question: Which chore does Anna do on Sundays?
questions.explanation: Anna hace la colada los domingos, lo cual se menciona claramente en el texto.

questions.question: True or False: Anna likes to iron clothes.
questions.explanation: Anna no le gusta planchar, pero su amiga sí, por eso se ayudan mutuamente.

questions.question: What can Anna cook well?
questions.explanation: Anna puede cocinar bien pasta y ensaladas, lo que a sus amigos les gusta mucho.

questions.question: Why does Anna enjoy washing the dishes?
options: She likes the smell of soap.
She listens to music while doing it.
She doesn't have to do it often.
questions.answer: She listens to music while doing it.
questions.explanation: A Anna no le molesta lavar los platos porque escucha música mientras lo hace.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT mentioned in the passage?
options: Anna enjoys cooking for her friends.
questions.explanation: El pasaje menciona que Anna no puede hornear pasteles muy bien, por lo tanto, esta opción no se menciona.

content.title: Práctica de pronunciación: Estrés de palabras en inglés
content.instructions: En este ejercicio, practicaremos el estrés de palabras en inglés. Escucha cada oración y repite después del modelo. Concéntrate en acentuar correctamente las palabras resaltadas. Sigue los consejos de pronunciación para mejorar tu habilidad.

targetSentences.englishSentence: I can't find the broom in the cupboard.
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: No puedo encontrar la escoba en el armario.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Asegúrate de acentuar la palabra 'broom' correctamente.
targetSentences.focusPoints: Enfócate en el estrés de la palabra 'broom'.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No te olvides de acentuar la palabra correcta.

targetSentences.englishSentence: She can cook very delicious meals.
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: Ella puede cocinar comidas muy deliciosas.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Acentúa 'cook' correctamente para que se entienda bien.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: Evita decir 'cook' sin suficiente énfasis.

targetSentences.englishSentence: He must vacuum the living room.
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: Él debe pasar la aspiradora en la sala de estar.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: La palabra 'vacuum' tiene el estrés en la primera sílaba.
targetSentences.focusPoints: Concentrarse en la primera sílaba de 'vacuum'.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No pronunciar 'vacuum' con el estrés adecuado puede causar confusión.

targetSentences.englishSentence: They have to wash the dishes tonight.
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: Ellos tienen que lavar los platos esta noche.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Acentúa 'wash' para que la oración sea clara.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No olvides enfatizar la palabra 'wash'.

targetSentences.englishSentence: We should clean the windows tomorrow.
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: Deberíamos limpiar las ventanas mañana.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: La palabra 'clean' debe pronunciarse con un estrés claro.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: Asegúrate de no reducir el estrés en 'clean'.

content.title: Household Chores Exercise
content.instructions: Choose the correct answer for each question.

questions.question: Sara is going to clean the kitchen. She is going to do it ______.
questions.explanation: La respuesta correcta es 'herself' porque 'Sara' es una persona y necesitamos un pronombre reflexivo que coincida con ella.

questions.question: My brothers can't cook dinner. I will help ______.
questions.explanation: La respuesta correcta es 'them' porque se refiere a 'my brothers'. Usamos 'them' como pronombre de objeto para personas en plural.

questions.question: Can you vacuum the living room? I can't do ______ right now.
questions.explanation: La respuesta correcta es 'it' porque estamos hablando de 'vacuum the living room', que es una acción singular, por lo que usamos 'it'.

questions.question: They are going to do the laundry tomorrow. They have a lot of clothes, so they need to do ______.
questions.explanation: La respuesta correcta es 'it' porque 'do the laundry' se refiere a una acción singular que necesitan completar.

questions.sentence: I have a lot of clothes to wash. I can't do ___ alone. Can you help ___?
questions.explanation: En esta oración, 'it' se refiere a 'clothes' (ropa) como objeto directo y 'me' es un pronombre objeto que se refiere al hablante.

questions.sentence: My brother can't cook very well, but I can show ___ how to make a simple pasta dish.
questions.explanation: Aquí, 'him' se usa como pronombre objeto para referirse a 'my brother'.

questions.sentence: There are many dirty dishes. We should clean ___ before dinner.
questions.explanation: En este caso, 'them' se refiere a 'dishes' (platos) y se usa como pronombre objeto plural.

questions.sentence: I can't find the broom. Have you seen ___?
questions.explanation: 'It' es el pronombre objeto que se usa para referirse al 'broom' (escoba) en singular.

questions.sentence: We have to vacuum the living room. Can you do ___ now?
questions.explanation: Aquí, 'it' se refiere a la tarea de pasar la aspiradora en la sala de estar y se usa como pronombre objeto.

questions.sentence: My sister is busy, so I will help ___ with her chores.
questions.explanation: 'Her' es un pronombre objeto que se refiere a 'my sister'.

questions.sentence: We don't have any bread. Can you buy ___ on your way home?
questions.explanation: En este caso, 'some' se usa como cuantificador para referirse a 'bread' (pan), que es un sustantivo incontable.

questions.sentence: The kitchen is dirty. We must clean ___ before guests arrive.
questions.explanation: 'It' se usa como pronombre objeto para referirse a 'the kitchen' (la cocina) en singular.

sentences.hint: Usa 'must' para expresar obligación seguido de un verbo.
Usa 'going to' para hablar de planes futuros.

sentences.translation: No puedo ayudar en el jardín.
sentences.hint: Usa 'can't' para expresar incapacidad seguido de un verbo.
Usa 'would like to' para expresar un deseo.
Usa 'How many' para preguntar por cantidades contables.

content.title: Speaking Analysis: Household Chores
content.instructions: Choose the most appropriate option for each speaking situation

questions.scenario: You are talking with a friend about cleaning the kitchen.
questions.question: Friend: 'Can you help me clean the kitchen this afternoon?'
options: A) I can't, I have to finish my homework first.
B) I can't, I will finish my homework first.
C) I can't, I had to finish my homework first.
D) I can't, I finished my homework first.
questions.explanation: La respuesta correcta es 'I can't, I have to finish my homework first.' porque se usa 'have to' para expresar obligación presente.

questions.scenario: You are at a friend's house and they ask if you can cook.
questions.question: Friend: 'Can you cook dinner tonight?'
options: A) Yes, I can cook pasta.
B) Yes, I could cook pasta.
C) Yes, I am cooking pasta.
D) Yes, I will cook pasta.
questions.explanation: La opción 'Yes, I can cook pasta.' es correcta porque 'can' se usa para hablar de habilidad presente.

questions.scenario: You are describing what chores you did yesterday.
questions.question: Which sentence is correct?
options: A) I cleaned the living room and washed the dishes.
B) I clean the living room and wash the dishes.
C) I was cleaning the living room and wash the dishes.
D) I cleaning the living room and washed the dishes.
questions.explanation: La opción 'I cleaned the living room and washed the dishes.' es correcta ya que usa el pasado simple para acciones completadas en el pasado.

questions.scenario: You are talking about your ability to do chores.
questions.question: Which sentence is correct?
options: A) I can vacuum the floor but I can't reach the top shelf.
B) I can vacuum the floor but I don't can reach the top shelf.
C) I can vacuum the floor but I will can't reach the top shelf.
D) I can vacuum the floor but I am not can't reach the top shelf.
questions.explanation: La opción 'I can vacuum the floor but I can't reach the top shelf.' es correcta porque combina 'can' y 'can't' para expresar habilidad y falta de habilidad.

questions.scenario: You are explaining your weekend chores plan.
questions.question: Which sentence is correct?
options: A) I will clean my room and do the laundry.
B) I clean my room and do the laundry.
C) I was cleaning my room and do the laundry.
D) I cleaned my room and do the laundry.
questions.explanation: La opción 'I will clean my room and do the laundry.' es correcta porque 'will' se utiliza para hablar de planes futuros.

content.title: Word Search: Household Chores
content.instructions: Find the hidden words in the grid

clues.clue: To make something free from dirt.
To prepare food by heating it.
To clean a floor with a broom.
To remove dust from a surface.
To clean with water and soap.
To remove wrinkles from clothes with heat.
To clean the floor with a wet mop.
To cook food in an oven.
To clean the floor using a machine.
To clean something by rubbing it hard.

content.title: Crossword: Household Chores
content.instructions: Complete the crossword puzzle

items.clue: Use a broom to clean the floor
Remove dirt from surfaces
A machine that cleans carpets
Prepare food
Clean clothes with water and soap
Make clothes smooth with heat
Tool to clean floors with water
Cook in the oven

content.title: Household Chores: Daily Routines
content.textPassage: Every Saturday morning, Maria cleans her house. She starts with the kitchen. First, she washes the dishes and puts them in the cupboard. She cleans the stove and can't forget to wipe the counters. Maria loves cooking, so she organizes the spices on the shelf. After the kitchen, Maria vacuums the living room. She moves the furniture and makes sure the carpet is clean. Maria's brother, Juan, doesn't like cleaning. He can help her, but he prefers to play video games. Sometimes, Maria asks him to take out the trash. He can do that easily. When the cleaning is done, Maria and Juan prepare lunch. They make a salad and sandwiches. Maria can cut the vegetables, and Juan makes the sandwiches. They enjoy eating together after a busy morning.

questions.question: What does Maria start with when cleaning?
questions.explanation: Maria empieza con la cocina, como se menciona en el texto. Esto verifica la comprensión de los detalles específicos.

questions.question: What does Maria love doing?
questions.explanation: El texto dice que a Maria le encanta cocinar, lo que se relaciona con el vocabulario del tema.

questions.question: TRUE or FALSE: Maria's brother likes to help with cleaning.
questions.explanation: El texto indica que a Juan no le gusta limpiar, y prefiere jugar videojuegos.

questions.question: What can Juan do easily?
questions.explanation: Juan puede sacar la basura fácilmente, según se menciona en el texto.

questions.question: What do Maria and Juan do after cleaning?
questions.explanation: Después de limpiar, Maria y Juan preparan el almuerzo, lo que se describe claramente en el texto.

questions.question: What is NOT mentioned about the chores?
questions.explanation: El texto no menciona limpiar ventanas, lo que requiere que el estudiante infiera lo que no está incluido.

content.title: Práctica de pronunciación: Enfoque en el estrés de la oración
content.instructions: Practique la pronunciación enfocándose en el estrés de las oraciones. Escuche el audio, repita cada oración y preste atención a las palabras en negrita que tienen más énfasis. Usa las transcripciones fonéticas para ayudarte.

targetSentences.englishSentence: I **can** clean the kitchen, but I **can't** do the laundry.
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: Puedo limpiar la cocina, pero no puedo lavar la ropa.
targetSentences.phoneticTranscription: aɪ **kæn** kliːn ðə ˈkɪtʃɪn, bət aɪ **kænt** duː ðə ˈlɔːndri.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Pon énfasis en 'can' y 'can't' para mostrar contraste en lo que puedes y no puedes hacer.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: Evitar confundir 'can' con 'can't'. Asegúrate de que 'can't' suene fuerte y claro.

targetSentences.englishSentence: She **has** to cook dinner, and he **has** to set the table.
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: Ella tiene que cocinar la cena, y él tiene que poner la mesa.
targetSentences.phoneticTranscription: ʃiː **hæz** tuː kʊk ˈdɪnər, ənd hiː **hæz** tuː sɛt ðə ˈteɪbəl.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Resalta 'has' en ambas partes para mostrar la obligación de cada persona.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No olvides pronunciar claramente 'has' para que la obligación sea evidente.

targetSentences.englishSentence: We **should** vacuum the living room **today**.
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: Deberíamos aspirar la sala de estar hoy.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Enfatiza 'should' para indicar recomendación y 'today' para el tiempo.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No dejes que 'should' se pierda en la oración, ya que es clave para el consejo.

targetSentences.englishSentence: Can you **help** me with the dishes?
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: ¿Puedes ayudarme con los platos?
targetSentences.phoneticTranscription: kæn juː **hɛlp** miː wɪð ðə ˈdɪʃɪz?
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Asegúrate de que 'help' suene fuerte para mostrar que necesitas asistencia.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No murmures 'help'; es importante que se oiga claramente.

targetSentences.englishSentence: They **must** wash the car before it **rains**.
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: Deben lavar el coche antes de que llueva.
targetSentences.phoneticTranscription: ðeɪ **mʌst** wɒʃ ðə kɑːr bɪˈfɔːr ɪt **reɪnz**.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Dale fuerza a 'must' para indicar obligación y 'rains' para el evento futuro.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: Evita que 'must' suene débil, ya que es crucial para la obligación.

content.title: Household Chores: Object Pronouns and Can/Cant (Ability)
content.instructions: Choose the correct answer for each question. Explicaciones están en español.

questions.question: Can you help me with the dishes? I can't wash ___ by myself.
questions.explanation: La palabra 'dishes' (platos) es plural, por lo tanto, usamos 'them' como pronombre de objeto para referirnos a ellos.

questions.question: Maria and Tom are cooking dinner. She can make pasta and he can make salad. ___ can cook very well.
questions.explanation: 'They' es el pronombre sujeto correcto para referirse a 'Maria and Tom'. 'Them' es un pronombre de objeto y no es correcto en este contexto.

questions.question: I have to vacuum the living room. Can you vacuum ___ for me?
questions.explanation: 'Living room' es singular, así que usamos 'it' como pronombre de objeto para referirnos a la sala de estar.

questions.question: The children can't clean the windows. Can you help ___?
questions.explanation: 'The children' es plural, por lo que usamos 'them' como pronombre de objeto para referirnos a ellos.

questions.sentence: I will (help) my mom with cooking dinner tonight.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'will' para expresar decisiones espontáneas. Aquí, la persona decide ayudar a su madre en la cena.

questions.sentence: We are (clean) the house tomorrow.
questions.explanation: El uso del presente continuo ('are cleaning') indica un plan futuro. Aquí, se planea limpiar la casa mañana.

questions.sentence: She is going to (buy) groceries after work.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'going to' para hablar de planes e intenciones futuros. En este caso, ella planea comprar víveres después del trabajo.

questions.sentence: The kitchen is the (clean) room in the house.
questions.explanation: Usamos adjetivos en superlativo para describir el grado más alto de una cualidad. Aquí, 'cleanest' indica que la cocina es la más limpia de todas las habitaciones.

questions.sentence: You should (wash) the dishes after eating.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'should' para dar consejos. Aquí, se aconseja lavar los platos después de comer.

questions.sentence: I can't (find) my keys. Can you help me?
questions.explanation: Usamos 'can't' para expresar habilidad o posibilidad negativa. Aquí, indica que la persona no puede encontrar sus llaves.

questions.sentence: The bathroom is going to (be) cleaned tomorrow.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'going to' para expresar planes. Aquí, se planea limpiar el baño mañana.

questions.sentence: You must (tidy) your room before guests arrive.
questions.explanation: Usamos 'must' para expresar obligación. Aquí, se indica que es necesario ordenar la habitación antes de que lleguen los invitados.

sentences.hint: Sujeto + can + verbo base + objeto.

sentences.translation: No puedo cocinar la cena esta noche.
sentences.hint: Sujeto + can't + verbo base + objeto.
Can + sujeto + verbo base + objeto + ?

sentences.translation: Ellos no pueden usar la aspiradora.
sentences.hint: Sujeto + can't + verbo base + objeto.

sentences.translation: Ella puede ayudarnos con la colada.
sentences.hint: Sujeto + can + verbo base + objeto.

content.title: Speaking Analysis: Household Chores
content.instructions: Choose the most appropriate option for each speaking situation

questions.scenario: Your friend asks if you can help with cleaning the house this weekend.
questions.question: What is the most appropriate response?
options: A: Sure, I can help you clean the house.
B: I cannot help you with cleaning.
C: I will help you clean.
D: Helping you clean is what I do.
questions.explanation: La opción 'A' es la respuesta más adecuada porque usa 'can' para expresar habilidad y disposición para ayudar.

questions.scenario: You are at a friend's house and they ask if you want to cook dinner together.
questions.question: How would you respond informally?
options: A: Yes, let us proceed with the cooking.
B: Sure, I can't wait to start cooking!
C: I would be delighted to assist in the culinary process.
questions.explanation: 'B' es la respuesta informal adecuada porque usa contracciones y expresa entusiasmo de manera casual.

questions.scenario: You're explaining how to clean the living room to your younger sibling.
questions.question: Which idiomatic expression fits best?
options: A: Let's hit the nail on the head and clean.
B: Let's hit the sack and start cleaning.
C: Let's get the ball rolling and clean.
D: Let's take it with a grain of salt and clean.
questions.explanation: La expresión 'C' es adecuada ya que 'get the ball rolling' significa comenzar algo, como limpiar.

questions.scenario: You're discussing chores with your roommate and want to add a related point.
questions.question: Which discourse marker should you use?
options: A: In addition, we need to vacuum the living room.
B: Despite that, we need to vacuum the living room.
C: Nonetheless, we need to vacuum the living room.
D: However, we need to vacuum the living room.
questions.explanation: La frase 'A' usa 'In addition' correctamente para agregar información sobre las tareas del hogar.

questions.scenario: You're asking your neighbor if they could water your plants while you're away.
questions.question: Which is the most polite way to ask?
options: A: Water my plants when I'm away, please.
B: Could you water my plants while I'm away?
C: Watering my plants is your task when I'm gone.
D: You must water my plants while I'm away.
questions.explanation: La opción 'B' es la más cortés ya que utiliza 'Could you' para hacer una petición educada.

questions.scenario: You're explaining to a friend how to pronounce 'vacuum' in English.
questions.question: Which word stress pattern is correct?
questions.explanation: La opción 'A' muestra el patrón correcto de acentuación, con énfasis en la primera sílaba.

content.title: Word Search: Household Chores
content.instructions: Find the hidden words in the grid

clues.clue: To make something free of dirt or mess.
To prepare food by heating it.
To remove dirt or dust from the floor with a broom.
To clean something with water and usually soap.
To make clothes smooth using heat.
To remove fine particles from surfaces.
To clean floors with a wet tool.
To cook food in an oven.
To clean floors using a machine that sucks up dirt.
To clean something by rubbing it hard.

content.title: Crossword: Household Chores
content.instructions: Complete the crossword puzzle

items.clue: What you do to make something tidy
To remove dirt from surfaces
To prepare food
To make clothes smooth using heat
To clean the floor with a broom
To clean with water and soap

content.title: Household Chores
content.textPassage: Every weekend, Maria does her household chores. She can clean the house very well. First, she dusts the furniture. Then, she vacuums the carpets. Maria also loves cooking. She cooks lunch for her family every Sunday. She makes delicious pasta, and her family always eats it with joy. However, Maria cannot do everything by herself. Her brother, Carlos, helps her. He can wash the dishes and takes out the trash. Sometimes, he even helps with the laundry. Maria enjoys her chores because she listens to music while working. She says it makes the chores more fun.

questions.question: What is the main idea of the passage?
options: Maria likes to cook every day.
Maria and Carlos share household chores.
Maria listens to music at work.
questions.answer: Maria and Carlos share household chores.
questions.explanation: La idea principal del texto es que Maria y Carlos comparten las tareas del hogar durante el fin de semana.

questions.question: What does Maria do first when cleaning?
questions.explanation: El texto indica que Maria primero quita el polvo de los muebles antes de pasar la aspiradora.

questions.question: True or False: Maria cannot cook.
questions.explanation: Es falso porque el texto dice que a Maria le encanta cocinar y prepara almuerzo para su familia cada domingo.

questions.question: What does Carlos do to help with the chores?
questions.explanation: Carlos ayuda con las tareas sacando la basura, entre otras cosas.

questions.question: Why does Maria enjoy doing chores?
options: Because she doesn't have to work.
questions.explanation: Maria disfruta de hacer las tareas porque escucha música mientras trabaja, lo que hace que las tareas sean más divertidas.

questions.question: Which task is NOT mentioned in the passage?
questions.explanation: La limpieza de las ventanas no se menciona en el texto; se mencionan otras tareas como lavar los platos y pasar la aspiradora.

content.title: Práctica de Pronunciación: Estrés de Palabras
content.instructions: Escucha las oraciones y repite en voz alta. Presta atención al estrés de las palabras en inglés. Usa los consejos de pronunciación para mejorar tu acento.

targetSentences.englishSentence: I can clean the kitchen on Saturday.
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: Puedo limpiar la cocina el sábado.
targetSentences.phoneticTranscription: /aɪ kæn kliːn ðə ˈkɪtʃ.ən ɒn ˈsæt.ə.deɪ/
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Enfatiza la primera sílaba de 'kitchen' y 'Saturday' para una pronunciación clara.
targetSentences.focusPoints: Palabras con más de una sílaba como 'kitchen' y 'Saturday'.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No cambiar el estrés a la última sílaba de 'Saturday'.

targetSentences.englishSentence: She can't cook dinner tonight.
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: Ella no puede cocinar la cena esta noche.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Asegúrate de enfatizar la primera sílaba en 'dinner'.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No poner el estrés en la primera sílaba de 'dinner'.

targetSentences.englishSentence: They can wash the car tomorrow.
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: Pueden lavar el coche mañana.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: En 'tomorrow', enfatiza la segunda sílaba para sonar natural.
targetSentences.focusPoints: Palabras con más de una sílaba como 'tomorrow'.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No enfatizar correctamente la segunda sílaba de 'tomorrow'.

targetSentences.englishSentence: I must vacuum the living room.
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: Debo pasar la aspiradora en la sala de estar.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: Enfoca en la primera sílaba de 'vacuum' y 'living'.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: Transferir el estrés a la última sílaba de 'vacuum'.

targetSentences.englishSentence: We should dust the furniture.
targetSentences.spanishTranslation: Deberíamos quitar el polvo de los muebles.
targetSentences.pronunciationTips: En 'furniture', asegúrate de que el estrés esté en la primera sílaba.
targetSentences.commonMistakes: No cambiar el estrés a la última sílaba de 'furniture'.

content.title: Household Chores: Object Pronouns and Can/Cannot
content.instructions: Choose the correct answer for each question.

questions.question: Can you help me clean the windows? I can't reach ______.
questions.explanation: La palabra 'windows' es plural, por lo que se debe usar el pronombre objeto 'them'.

questions.question: She is cooking dinner right now. Can you set the table for ______?
questions.explanation: El pronombre objeto correcto para referirse a 'she' es 'her'.

questions.question: We have a lot of clothes to fold. Can you help us with ______?
questions.explanation: La palabra 'clothes' es plural, por lo que se debe usar el pronombre objeto 'them'.

questions.question: I can vacuum the living room, but I can't do ______ alone.
questions.explanation: La palabra 'vacuum' se refiere a una acción específica y singular, por lo que se usa 'it'.

questions.question: They are washing the dishes. Can you dry ______?
questions.explanation: La palabra 'dishes' es plural, por lo que se debe usar el pronombre objeto 'them'.

questions.question: He can make a cake, but he can't decorate ______ without help.
questions.explanation: La palabra 'cake' es singular, por lo que se debe usar el pronombre objeto 'it'.

questions.sentence: I _______ clean the windows every Saturday.
questions.explanation: Se utiliza 'can' para indicar habilidad. Aquí significa que la persona tiene la capacidad de limpiar las ventanas.

questions.sentence: She _______ make a cake because she doesn't have any flour.
questions.explanation: 'Can't' se usa para indicar que alguien no tiene la habilidad o posibilidad de hacer algo. En este caso, no puede hacer un pastel porque no tiene harina.

questions.sentence: Can you help _______ with the laundry? I need some help.
questions.explanation: Se utiliza 'me' como pronombre objeto cuando la acción del verbo recae sobre la primera persona del singular.

questions.sentence: I can't find my keys. Have you seen _______?
questions.explanation: Se usa 'them' como pronombre objeto para referirse a objetos en plural (las llaves).

questions.sentence: We _______ vacuum the living room today.
questions.explanation: Se utiliza 'can' para expresar que es posible o que se tiene la capacidad de aspirar la sala de estar.

questions.sentence: She can't cook dinner because _______ is too tired.
questions.explanation: 'She' es un pronombre sujeto que se utiliza para indicar quién está demasiado cansado para cocinar.

questions.sentence: He _______ clean the kitchen after dinner.
questions.explanation: 'Can' se usa para indicar que tiene la capacidad de limpiar la cocina después de la cena.

questions.sentence: Please give _______ the broom. I want to sweep the floor.
questions.explanation: Se utiliza 'me' como pronombre objeto para indicar que la persona que habla quiere recibir la escoba.
